title: R45254
content: The Financial Services and General Government (FSGG) appropriations bill funds independent agencies in Title V, which manage federal property, regulate financial institutions, and oversee mail delivery. The bill also covers general provisions in Title VII and Cuba sanctions in Title I, along with funding for the Department of the Treasury, Executive Office of the President, judiciary, and District of Columbia. Mandatory retirement accounts are typically funded in Title VI. The FSGG appropriations bills fund independent agencies that manage federal property, regulate financial institutions, and oversee mail delivery. The bills also address financial regulation issues in additional titles. The House and Senate FSGG bills fund the same agencies, except for the Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) which is funded through the Agriculture appropriations bill in the House. President Trump's FY2018 budget request included approximately $3.1 billion for the independent agencies funded through the FSGG. The House Committee on Appropriations reported the Financial Services and General Government Appropriations Act, 2018, with a total of approximately $3.1 billion for independent agencies funded through the FSGG appropriations bill, including $330 million for the CFTC. The FY2018 funding for the FSGG independent agencies in the reported bill would have been $253 million, with an additional $248 million for the CFTC included in the Agriculture appropriations bill. The combined total of $501 million would have been about $2.6 billion below the President's FY2018 request. The bill H.R. 3354 was amended multiple times, resulting in $488 million funding for FSGG independent agencies. The House passed the bill on September 14, 2017. The Senate Committee on Appropriations released a recommended draft bill with $593 million funding for independent agencies, $2.5 billion below the President's request. Congress passed H.R. 601 / P.L. 115-56 for continuing appropriations through December 8, 2017. The continuing resolution (CR) P.L. 115-56 provided funding for FSGG agencies based on FY2017 rates with anomalies. Additional CRs were enacted on December 8, 2017 (P.L. 115-90), December 22, 2017 (P.L. 115-96), January 22, 2018 (P.L. 115-120), and February 9, 2018 (P.L. 115-123). P.L. 115-123 included extra funding for GSA and SBA to address hurricane disaster costs. The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2018 (H.R. 1625/P.L. 115-141) was enacted on March 23, 2018. The appropriations measure for FY2018 was passed in the House on March 22, 2018, and in the Senate on March 23, 2018. It included funding for FSGG agencies, with additional legislative language affecting financial regulation. Enacted appropriations totaled $4.7 billion, with significant differences in funding for agencies like the GSA, FCC, and EAC. EAC funding was mainly for grants to states for election reform programs. The FSGG appropriations bill provides funding for independent agencies with various functions. Table 2 and Table 3 detail the enacted amounts for FY2017, the President's FY2018 request, and the FY2018 amounts from different bills. EAC funding was primarily for grants to states for election reform programs. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission oversees derivatives markets, including futures and swaps. Its functions include market oversight, fraud prevention, and investor protection. Congressional authorization jurisdiction remains with the House and Senate Agriculture Committees due to the market's historical ties to agriculture. Appropriations for the CFTC fall under the Agriculture Appropriations Subcommittee. Following the financial crisis of 2008, reforms in the Dodd-Frank Act brought previously unregulated over-the-counter swaps markets under CFTC jurisdiction. This expanded the CFTC's oversight to include swaps markets with an estimated notional value of $240 trillion in the US, in addition to the already regulated futures and options markets with a $34 trillion notional value. The President requested $250 million for the CFTC's operations. The CFTC oversees swaps markets with an estimated $240 trillion notional value and futures/options markets with $34 trillion. The President requested $250 million for the CFTC in FY2018. The CPSC aims to reduce consumer harm from various products through safety standards, recalls, and data collection. The CPSC requested $123 million in appropriations for FY2018, $3 million less than FY2017. The reduction includes cuts to the VGBPSA grant program and salaries/expenses due to anticipated loss of employees. Budget allocation includes $5.5 million for workforce development, $78.1 million for consumer product safety, and $31.3 million for responding to emerging product hazards. The CPSC requested $123 million in appropriations for FY2018, with allocations for workforce development, consumer product safety, and responding to emerging product hazards. The House Appropriations Committee included $1.3 million for new VGBPSA grants, while also advising against adopting two proposed rules. The bill included two provisions for the CPSC: one regarding off-highway vehicles safety and another on blade saw injuries. The Senate draft allocated $123 million for the CPSC, while P.L. 115-141 allocated $126 million and included the off-highway vehicles provision. The EAC was established under HAVA to provide grant funding for election reform programs and voting system standards. The Election Assistance Commission (EAC) was established under HAVA to provide grant funding for election reform programs and voting system standards. The EAC does not have new rulemaking authority under HAVA, but it took over responsibilities for the National Voter Registration Act from the FEC. The Department of Justice enforces HAVA. The President's budget request for FY2018 included $9.2 million for the EAC, with $1.5 million allocated to the National Institute of Standards and Technology for testing guidelines for voting systems. The House passed a bill with $7 million for the EAC, while the Senate draft bill proposed $9.2 million. P.L. 115-141 ultimately appropriated $10.1 million for the EAC. The Senate draft bill allocated $9.2 million for the Election Assistance Commission (EAC), while P.L. 115-141 provided $10.1 million directly for the EAC, with $1.5 million to be transferred to NIST. Additionally, $380 million was appropriated for improving election administration. The Federal Communications Commission (FCC) is an independent agency regulating communications, funded by regulatory fees collected from license holders and other entities. The FCC is funded by regulatory fees collected from license holders and other entities. For FY2018, the FCC requested a budget of $322 million, with a cap of $111.15 million for spectrum auction administration. P.L. 115-141 appropriated $322 million for the FCC, with an additional $600 million for the TV broadcaster relocation fund. The FDIC's Office of the Inspector General is funded through deposit insurance funds outside of the appropriations process. The FDIC's Office of the Inspector General (OIG) is funded through deposit insurance funds to ensure independence. The President's FY2018 request included $39.1 million for the OIG, which was approved in P.L. 115-141. The FEC enforces campaign finance regulations and administers the presidential public financing system. The FEC administers the presidential public financing system. For FY2018, the agency requested $71.25 million, $7.9 million less than FY2017. Congress appropriated the additional $7.9 million in anticipation of the FEC's office space lease expiring. The agency is scheduled to move to a new location in FY2018. Approximately 90% of the budget is expected to fund salaries, benefits, IT, and facilities expenses. Other sections of the legislation contained provisions related to campaign finance policy. The House-passed version of campaign finance policy includes provisions prohibiting the SEC from issuing rules on disclosure of political contributions, limiting enforcement of a FECA provision, and prohibiting reporting political contributions for government contracts. The enacted law included these provisions as well. The FEC requested $71.25 million for FY2018, with most of the budget allocated for salaries, benefits, IT, and facilities expenses. The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) is responsible for protecting consumers from deceptive practices and promoting competition. Its funding comes from direct appropriations, premerger filing fees, and Do-Not-Call Registry fees. In FY2017, the FTC had an enacted budget of $313.0 million. In FY2017, the FTC's budget included direct appropriations, HSR filing fees, and DNC registry fees. The President's FY2018 request proposed a budget cut, with reduced salaries and expenses. The House passed H.R. 3354 with the same total amount requested by the Administration for the FTC in FY2018. The House Appropriations Committee directed the FTC to submit a report on enforcing privacy laws for consumer information collected by internet service providers. The committee also requested a report on the benefits of credit education services and the impact of the Credit Repair Organizations Act on new products and technology. The Senate draft bill allocated $306.3 million for the FTC from various sources. P.L. 115-141 also appropriated $306.3 million for the FTC. The FTC receives funding from direct appropriations, HSR filing fees, and DNC registry fees. The General Services Administration manages federal procurement policies, property disposal, and facilities for former Presidents. Funding for GSA's real property activities comes from the Federal Buildings Fund, which is replenished by rental payments from federal agencies leasing GSA space. Congress allocates the fund's revenue for construction, repairs, rental payments, and other building expenses. The General Services Administration (GSA) manages federal procurement policies, property disposal, and facilities for former Presidents. GSA's real property activities are funded by the Federal Buildings Fund (FBF), which covers leasing, installment payments, and building operations expenses. The FBF has limitations set by Congress, and a negative total occurs when funds available for expenditure are less than expected revenue. GSA's operating accounts are funded separately from the FBF, with total funding calculated by adding FBF appropriations and operating account appropriations. The President's FY2018 request, House-passed bill, Senate draft bill, and enacted amounts from P.L. 115-141 and P.L. 115-123 for GSA's real property activities in FY2018 are compared. The President proposed $9.951 billion, the House passed $7.842 billion, the Senate draft bill $7.809 billion, and P.L. 115-141 provided $9.074 billion. These amounts show variations from FY2017 enacted appropriations and the President's request. The President's FY2018 request for GSA's real property activities was $9.951 billion, with the enacted amount from P.L. 115-141 at $9.074 billion. The request included funding for new accounts such as the Asset Proceeds and Space Management Fund and the Environmental Review Improvement Fund, aimed at reforming the environmental review process and federal permitting. The President requested $228 million for a new Technology Modernization Fund to improve agency IT systems. The House-passed bill allocated $240 million for GSA's operating accounts, while the Senate draft bill proposed $234 million. P.L. 115-141 provided $335 million for GSA's operating accounts, $81 million more than FY2017. Additionally, P.L. 115-123 included an extra $127 million. The FSGG appropriations bill included $127 million in emergency supplemental GSA appropriations in response to recent disasters. It funds four agencies with personnel management functions: FLRA, MSPB, OPM, and OSC. FLRA administers Title VII of the Civil Service Reform Act of 1978, giving federal employees the right to join or form a union and to bargain. The Federal Service Labor-Management Relations Statute (FSLMRS) grants federal employees the right to join or form a union and collectively bargain over employment terms. Certain agencies like FBI, CIA, GAO, NSA, TVA, FLRA, FSIP, and Secret Service are excluded. The FLRA consists of a three-member authority and the Office of General Counsel, appointed by the President for five-year terms with Senate approval. The Federal Service Impasses Panel (FSIP) resolves disputes over labor practices and bargaining units. The President appoints members, and the panel addresses negotiation impasses. The FLRA's General Counsel office manages representation elections and investigates labor practices. The President requested $26.2 million for FY2018, with 121 full-time equivalents. The MSPB protects the civil service merit system as an independent agency. The Merit Systems Protection Board (MSPB) is an independent agency that adjudicates appeals related to personnel actions, federal employee complaints, and retirement benefits. The President's FY2018 budget requested $46.8 million for the MSPB, which would fund 235 full-time equivalents and support IT infrastructure projects. The House, Senate, and P.L. 115-141 all appropriated the requested amount. OPM is responsible for personnel management of the federal government. The President's budget requested $148.3 million for OPM salaries and expenses, including funding for IT infrastructure modernization and acquisition workforce capabilities. Additionally, appropriations were requested for trust fund transfers and OIG expenses for FY2018. OPM also requested an increase in FTE employment level for FY2018. OPM requested an increase in FTE employment level for FY2018 to 6,376, up by 500 FTEs from FY2017. The budget submission highlighted the need for IT infrastructure investments for security and to meet changing business needs. The OIG will continue oversight activities, including audits, investigations, and evaluations of various OPM programs. Additionally, the OIG will advance the prescription drug audit program and FEHBP claims data warehouse initiative. The OIG will provide oversight for the agency's IT infrastructure project, including data center consolidation and potential mainframe migrations. Appropriations for OPM salaries and expenses, trust fund transfers, OIG salaries and expenses, and OIG trust fund transfers were allocated in P.L. 115-141. The Comptroller General would be required to submit a report evaluating OPM's actions to prevent data breaches. The report accompanying H.R. 3280 outlined directives for OPM, including modernizing the federal retirement process and improving cybersecurity measures. It also emphasized the need for OPM to prioritize retirement processing and implement a fully automated electronic filing system. Monthly progress reports to Congress on backlog issues were also mandated. The House committee directed OPM to prioritize security clearance processing, IT security upgrades, and provide biannual progress reports on the NBIB implementation plan to Congress. The OPM OIG must submit a report to Congress assessing the implementation of NBIB, staffing needs, performance issues, costs, governance structure, and recommendations. The House committee emphasized the importance of OPM fulfilling critical functions like recruitment, retention, and workforce development. OPM was directed to report on a plan to improve federal recruitment and hiring processes by reducing barriers and delays. The House committee directed federal agencies to increase recruitment efforts in the United States, territories, Hispanic Serving Institutions, and Historically Black Colleges and Universities. OPM was encouraged to review GAO recommendations on hiring authorities and provide resources for critical positions. OPM must report on actions to improve hiring of CyberCorps graduates and acquisition planning to the House and Senate Appropriations Committees. OPM is directed to improve acquisition planning and cybersecurity measures in response to GAO recommendations. Reports and briefings on modernization efforts and retirement backlog are also required. OPM is directed to provide monthly progress reports on the retirement claims backlog. Mandatory appropriations for health benefits, life insurance, and retirement accounts are outlined in H.R. 3354 and P.L. 115-141. The Congressional Budget Office estimated funds for annuitants' health benefits, life insurance, and civil service retirement. The OSC is an independent federal agency focused on investigative and prosecutorial tasks. The OSC is an independent federal agency focused on investigative and prosecutorial tasks, safeguarding the merit system by protecting federal employees and applicants from prohibited personnel practices. The President's budget requested $26.5 million for the OSC in FY2018, with an estimated FTE employment level of 144, an increase from the previous year. The budget submission projected stable trends in whistleblower disclosure, Hatch Act, and prohibited personnel practice cases, with around 6,000 new cases received each year. The requested funding aims to meet rising demand for services, protect whistleblowers in the VA and other agencies, and manage increasing case levels. The National Archives and Records Administration (NARA) is an independent agency created to preserve government records and make them publicly available. The Administration requested $376 million for NARA for FY2018, while H.R. 3354 included $380 million and P.L. 115-141 appropriated $403.2 million. The National Credit Union Administration (NCUA) manages the Community Development Revolving Loan Fund (CDRLF) to assist low-income credit unions. It provides low-interest loans, deposits, and technical assistance grants. Earnings from the CDRLF fund grants for improving operations and addressing safety and soundness issues. The President requested no appropriation for the CDRLF. The President requested no money for the CDRLF in FY2018, while H.R. 3354 and the Senate draft bill both proposed $2 million, the same as in FY2017. The Office of Government Ethics (OGE) is an independent agency overseeing financial disclosure and ethics in the executive branch. OGE's FY2018 budget request was $16.4 million, a $349,000 increase. The President's FY2018 budget request for the Office of Government Ethics (OGE) was $16.4 million, a $349,000 increase from FY2017. Both H.R. 3354 and the Senate draft bill allocated $16.4 million for OGE, which was appropriated in P.L. 115-141. The Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board (PCLOB) was reconstituted as an independent agency in 2007 to ensure privacy and civil liberties concerns are considered in laws and policies related to national security. The Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board (PCLOB) was reconstituted in 2007 to protect the nation from terrorism while balancing privacy and civil liberties. The President requested $8 million for PCLOB in FY2018, down from $10.1 million in FY2017. The board advises the President and executive branch on privacy issues and provides annual reports to Congress. The PCLOB was appropriated $8 million in FY2018, down from $10.1 million in FY2017. The PCAOB, created by the Sarbanes-Oxley Act, is funded through accounting support fees from public companies. Sarbanes-Oxley also established a scholarship program funded by PCAOB penalties for accounting students. The scholarship program funded by PCAOB penalties for accounting students is administered by an outside vendor under PCAOB rules. Section 620 of the Senate draft bill proposed allocating $1 million for scholarships, similar to previous years. The SEC enforces securities laws to protect investors and maintain fair markets, with its budget determined separately. The SEC's budget is funded through fees collected from securities exchanges, offsetting its appropriations under the Dodd-Frank Act. The President's FY2018 request was $1.85 billion, with additional funding for a new headquarters lease. The House passed $1.90 billion for the SEC in FY2018, while the Senate proposed $1.85 billion. Additionally, the Dodd-Frank Act established an SEC reserve fund for long-term expenses. The SEC established a reserve fund for long-term expenses funded by registration fees, with a cap of $100 million. In FY2017, $25 million was rescinded from the fund. The President's FY2018 request would rescind $25 million, while the House proposed rescinding the entire $75 million in the fund. The Senate draft bill did not propose any rescissions. P.L. 115-141 appropriated $1.90 billion for the SEC, offset by fee collections, with $245 million allocated for the headquarters lease. The Selective Service System (SSS) is an independent federal agency operating under the Military Selective Service Act. It serves the emergency manpower needs of the military by conscripting personnel when directed by Congress and the President. Most males aged 18-25 in the US are required to register with the SSS. The draft ended in 1973, but in 1980, President Carter proposed standby draft registration for both men and women. Congress approved funds for male-only registration in June 1980. The Selective Service System (SSS) operates under the Military Selective Service Act to serve the military's manpower needs. Most males aged 18-25 in the US must register with the SSS. President Carter proposed standby draft registration for men and women in 1980. Funding for the SSS has remained stable in absolute dollars but decreased in inflation-adjusted terms. The Small Business Administration administers programs to assist small businesses, including loan guarantees, low-interest loans, disaster relief, training, and advocacy within the federal government. The President requested $829.1 million for the Small Business Administration (SBA) for FY2018, with allocations for various programs including salaries, entrepreneurial development, business loans, disaster assistance, and advocacy. Authorization levels were also requested for loan guaranty programs and the Small Business Investment Company program. Additionally, a rescission of $2.6 million was requested. The House-passed bill allocated $862.8 million for the SBA in FY2018, $33.7 million more than the Administration's request. $260.0 million was designated for salaries and expenses, $231.1 million for entrepreneurial development and noncredit programs. The bill also allowed Microloan intermediaries to use up to 50% of their technical assistance grant funds on prospective borrowers and contracts with third parties. The Committee on Appropriations' chairmen recommended a draft bill for the SBA in FY2018, allocating $886.3 million, $57.1 million more than the Administration's request. $269.5 million was for salaries and expenses, $245.1 million for entrepreneurial development and noncredit programs. The final appropriation in P.L. 115-141 was $700.8 million, with $268.5 million for salaries and expenses, $247.1 million for entrepreneurial development, and no funding for disaster assistance due to previous allocations for hurricane costs in 2017. The SBA received $1.66 billion, mainly for hurricane disaster costs in 2017. The USPS generates revenue from mail users but receives appropriations for free mailing privileges. Congress authorized appropriations for USPS in the 1993 RFRA, including a $29 million annual reimbursement until 2035 for below-cost postal services. The Postal Accountability and Enhancement Act (PAEA) enacted in 2006 affected postal appropriations, requiring USPSOIG and PRC budget requests to go directly to Congress and OMB. Funding for these agencies comes from the Postal Service Fund, with USPSOIG's budget treated as part of USPS's budget. The President requested $58.1 million for the Postal Service Fund in the FY2018 budget submission, which is $23.4 million more than the USPS's FY2017 appropriation. The President also requested $71.3 million for USPS in FY2018, $36.7 million more than its FY2017 appropriation. The House, Senate, and P.L. 115-141 all appropriated $58.1 million for USPS. Additionally, the President requested $234.7 million for USPSOIG in FY2018, which is $19 million less than its FY2017 appropriation. The USPSOIG's FY2018 budget request is $275.2 million, an increase of $21.6 million from its FY2017 appropriation. The House-passed bill proposed $234.7 million, while the Senate draft bill suggested $245 million. The PRC requested $14.4 million for FY2018, slightly less than its FY2017 appropriation. The House-passed bill included postal policy provisions like maintaining six-day mail delivery. The bill proposed postal policy provisions including maintaining six-day mail delivery, providing free mail for overseas voting and the blind, and prohibiting fees for child support agencies. The House committee also requested a report on increasing sales of the Multinational Species semipostal stamp. The Trump Administration aims to reduce costs and improve revenue through reforms. The Trump Administration proposed reforms to reduce costs and improve revenue for the Postal Service, including adjusting mail delivery frequency, shifting to centralized delivery, and modifying rate structures. These changes aim to address retiree health and pension costs, with projected savings of $46 billion over 10 years. The United States Tax Court (USTC) is an independent judicial body with jurisdiction over tax matters. It was appropriated $51.2 million in FY2017, with a request for $53.2 million in FY2018. However, P.L. 115-141 only allocated $50.7 million for the USTC in FY2018. The FSGG Appropriations Act allocated $50.7 million for the USTC in FY2018. General provisions in the Act apply government-wide, with language that has been reiterated for several years. New provisions proposed but not enacted for FY2018 include adjustments to discretionary spending limits if new budget authority exceeds the limit. The FY2018 budget proposal includes adjustments to discretionary spending limits, with a cap of 0.2% of the total limits. DACA recipients may be eligible for federal government employment. The Treasury Department's OFAC administers Cuba embargo regulations, with H.R. 3280 proposing sanctions that were not included in the final bill. The proposed sanctions on Cuba, including restrictions on importing confiscated property, were not included in the final bill. This measure aimed to prevent the importation of rum and tobacco products by authorized U.S. travelers. A similar provision was considered in the previous Congress but was not enacted. The provision prohibits OFAC from licensing payment of trademark fees for marks confiscated by the Cuban government without owner consent. This relates to a dispute over the Havana Club trademark between a Cuban company and Bacardi Limited. OFAC issued a specific license for the Cuban company to renew the trademark, which was subsequently renewed until 2026 by the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office.
